description: From New Latin encyclopaedia (“general education”), from Renaissance Ancient Greek ἐγκυκλοπαιδεία (enkuklopaideía, “education in the circle of arts and sciences”), a mistaken univerbated form of Koine Greek ἐγκύκλιος παιδείᾱ (enkúklios paideíā, “education in the circle of arts and sciences”), from ἐγκύκλιος (enkúklios, “circular”) + παιδείᾱ (paideíā, “child-rearing, education”).

nouns.description: encyclopedia (plural encyclopedias or encyclopediae or encyclopediæ)

entries.meaning: A comprehensive reference work (often spanning several printed volumes) with articles (usually arranged in alphabetical order, or sometimes arranged by category) on a range of subjects, sometimes general, sometimes limited to a particular field.
examples: I only use the library for the encyclopedia, as we’ve got most other books here.
His life's work as a four-volume encyclopedia of aviation topics.

entries.meaning: (dated) The circle of arts and sciences; a comprehensive summary of knowledge, or of a branch of knowledge.
